etymologies: Middle English; earliest use found in Journal of English and Germanic Philology. Apparently a variant of penide (although attested slightly earlier) or of its etymon Middle French pénide, with alteration of the ending; compare Middle French penites, Italian peneto, penneto, pennito

definitions: A piece or stick of barley-sugar or a similar confection; = penide. Usually in plural.
Formerly (especially in northern England): a 19th century trade term for a toffee-like sweet flavoured with lemon, peppermint, etc.
